B0000021RL|5.0|After the relatively downbeat pop of \\"Chicago VI,\\" this album shows an energetic Chicago with a positive musical outlook. While the pop element is retained, there are also incredible jazz moments that can take you back to the first three Chicago albums.<br /><br />The first five tracks are instrumentals, yielding more than 25 minutes of wonderful music that alternates between jazz, progressive jazz, jazz-rock, and other combinations that are easy to lose in the complexity of the music. The instruments include congas, horns, a flute, drums, guitars and keyboards, including a mellotron, Fender Rhodes, ARP synthesizer, and clavinet.<br /><br />\\"Prelude to Aire\\" provides an initial indication of the flavor of the instrumentals with a strongly African influenced beat. If you liked Paul Simon's \\"Graceland,\\" you should also like \\"Prelude to Aire.\\" \\"Aire\\" is a jazz instrumental with but a flavor of the introductory song. Peter Cetera and Terry Kath get to strut their stuff in the second half of the song, with Terry Kath turning funky for a portion of his lead.<br /><br />\\"Aire\\" is complex and relatively long at almost six and a half minutes, but the following instrumental, \\"Devil's Sweet,\\" is even longer. Portions of this ten minute composition are introspective, allowing jazz noodling of a core musical theme. Certain portions remind me of some of King Crimson's more experimental 70s work. The mixture of 50s retro style with Jazz and rock creates an interesting instrumental composition that requires multiple listens for full appreciation. \\"Italian from New York\\" fits well with the previous instrumentals. This instrumental begins with sound effects that are retro, yet modern. The sound effects are married to horns and later a funky guitar to create a fusion that is new and old, interesting and unique. The last instrumental composition, \\"Hanky Panky,\\" sets up the transition from the instrumental mini-suite to the first song of the album. \\"Hanky Panky\\" is a celebration of music and jazz and declares its enthusiasm for the music that came before and the music that comes after.<br /><br />The first song keeps a jazz theme for continuity with the opening instrumentals. The vocals have a Beatle's style when they open, and \\"Life Saver's\\" peppy beat sets the optimistic tone for the music of this CD. \\"Happy Man\\" is a mellow pop love song from Peter Cetera. The pace is slower than the earlier songs, and yet the song is a celebration, with upbeat percussion and vocals.<br /><br />The next song was the first hit from this album. An edited version of \\"(I've Been) Searchin' So Long\\" was backed by \\"Byblos\\" in release. The single reached #9 on the Hot 100 and #8 on the Easy Listening charts. As was typical of Chicago's music at that time, the music was very carefully arranged and heavily orchestrated. This pop song is flavored by horns rather than being a true jazz fusion. This song also features strings to further expand the complexity of the music. The vocals are arranged with similar complexity and make this song one of Chicago's all-time greats.<br /><br />I have no idea what \\"Mongonucleosis\\" is about. The lyrics are \\"Que pe chesa\\" repeated. The music is Hispanic-styled and fast. This music is easy on the ear and fun, maintaining the optimistic tone of the album. \\"Song of the Evergreens\\" is Terry Kath poetry. The lyrics are evocative and the complex music is rock. The repeated \\"snow\\" lyrics at the end of the song could be annoying, and yet they are not. Once again the music is catchy and tempts you to hum along. Near the end of the song the guitars break down into a funky sound characteristic of the mid-70s.<br /><br />\\"Byblos\\" is a lyrically complex song. This song is a story song in the tradition of those sung by Harry Chapin and Gordon Lightfoot. We never learn her name, but we know she affects those around her with her presence, an inner beauty that makes you long for her presence once more, while feeling comfortable just because she is in theworld. This song is yet another Terry Kath poem set to mellow and pretty music.<br /><br />The next song has always been one of my all-time Chicago favorites. \\"Wishing You Were Here\\" was ethereal and haunting well before that type of song was popular in rock. Chicago's vocals are enhanced by the presence of the Dennis and Carl Wilson of the Beach Boys and Al Jardine. There is also an interesting synthesizer contribution to this song that helps provide an eerie aspect to the song's ethereal air. This song is one that must be heard to be appreciated. This song reached #11 on the Hot 100 chart and #1 on the Easy Listening chart, backed by \\"Life Saver.\\"<br /><br />The next song charted #6 on the Hot 100 chart and also went to #1 on the easy listening chart. \\"Call on Me,\\" backed by \\"Prelude to Aire,\\" is a jazz-influenced pop love song. The lyrics are simple with yet more catchy pop hooks. The song speeds up at the end to rush through the last 30 seconds, leading into \\"Women Don't Want to Love Me.\\" This song has a funky blues rhythm and is a breakup song. Similarly, \\"Skinny Boy\\" also has a funky blues style. Both songs are by Robert Lamm.<br /><br />There are at least three versions of this CD available.  This version was released in 1995.  There is also a 1990 release and a 2002 remaster that includes a bonus track.  If you like Chicago's blues music you may prefer the version with the extra track.  You may wish to survey the available versions to determine which version best meets your needs before buying.<br /><br />From \\"Chicago Transit Authority\\" Chicago just seemed to get better and better. This CD shows pop influence, but there are just as many other influences, including jazz, blues and even Hispanic. This music is more than just great pop or rock; it is great music. If you are going to own music by Chicago, this CD is a must.because she is in the world. This song is yet another Terry Kath poem set to mellow and pretty music.  <br /> <br />The next song has always been one of my all-time Chicago favorites. \\"Wishing You Were Here\\" was ethereal and haunting well before that type of song was popular in rock. Chicago's vocals are enhanced by the presence of the Dennis and Carl Wilson of the Beach Boys and Al Jardine. There is also an interesting synthesizer contribution to this song that helps provide an eerie aspect to the song's ethereal air. This song is one that must be heard to be appreciated. The lyrics are simple with yet more catchy pop hooks. The song speeds up at the end to rush through the last 30 seconds, leading into \\"Women Don't Want to Love Me.\\" This song has a funky blues rhythm and is a breakup song. Similarly, \\"Skinny Boy\\" also has a funky blues style. Both songs are by Robert Lamm.  <br /> <br />There are at least three versions of this CD available.  This version was released in 1995.  There is also a 1990 release and a 2002 remaster that includes a bonus track.  If you like Chicago's blues music you may prefer the version with the extra track.  You may wish to survey the available versions to determine which version best meets your needs before buying. <br /> <br />From \\"Chicago Transit Authority\\" Chicago just seemed to get better and better. This CD shows pop influence, but there are just as many other influences, including jazz, blues and even Hispanic. This music is more than just great pop or rock; it is great music. If you are going to own music by Chicago, this CD is a must. <br />

1591840562|4.0|I've heard Guy Kawasaki speak to rooms of entrepreneurs-- he knows his stuff...and he knows how to inspire you to reach for your star...after you're prepared for the long stretch ahead...it's a marathon not a sprint ....and he knows the rules to help you get to the finish line. There are nine elements to his strategy including 1) positioning -- 2) pitching....(10 slides -- 20 minutes max) 3) business plan 4) bootstrapping 5) recruiting 6) partnering, 7 branding 8) rainmaking, 9) being a mensch....from raising capital to paying back society...he understands that there is a method to the madness of a start-up that is a far cry from the corporate world. Essential reading for everyone -- even if you sold your soul to the companys store-- because soon that store may be on sale too.....
B00004HYLF|5.0|The intensity and speed with which these guys play is simply frightening - it's inhuman actually and there are moments in the recording where I literally have to press stop and catch my breath.  OK, so that is overly dramatic but not too far from the truth.  The virtuosity on this 1976 album is mind-numbing and I personally feel that this album may be the high point of RTF's output - although I do like all of their albums and could easily be swayed one way or the other.<br /><br />The musicians on Romantic Warrior include former Miles Davis keyboardist Chick Corea (acoustic piano, Fender Rhodes electric piano, Hohner clavinet, Mini-moog, Moog 15, micro mini-moog, ARP Odyssey, Yamaha organ, Polymoog, marimba, and percussion); the fastest bass player on Earth, Stanley Clarke (Alembic bass w/flanger, piccolo bass, acoustic bass, bell tree, and hand bells); shredder Al DiMeola (electric/acoustic guitars, soprano guitar, hand bell, and slide whistle); and the thunderous Lenny White (drums/percussion).<br /><br />The six tracks range in length from 5'01\\" to 11'26\\", with another track reaching 10'52\\".  The longer pieces consist of excellent ensemble work interspersed with incredible solos.  Fortunately the solos do not go on for too long - then again these guys are top shelf and I could listen to Al DiMeola play scales at light speed all day long.  In general though, the music is an interesting blend of prog, some classical, straight jazz and jazz rock, with loads of synthesizers (that sometimes get incredibly spacey) and some searing and occasionally heavily distorted guitar playing (Al DiMeola's track Majestic Dance amply demonstrates this).  I think that it is interesting that the album liner notes point out that Chick's \\"flights from his multi-keyboard post, more than took care of the Yes/King Crimson art rock flank\\".  As a prog fan I definitely agree and was more than wowed by Chick's playing.  In addition to the rock elements, of which there are a lot, there are some shorter moments where things get slightly jazzy and Chick's acoustic piano and Stanleys' acoustic bass work can be heard (The Romantic Warrior).  For the most part though, these moments are far and few between and this is pretty much a rock record.<br /><br />This remastered album is OK and features good sound quality and restored album cover art, with some informative liner notes.<br /><br />As a fan of both prog and jazz rock, this album works for me on a number of levels.  I suppose though, that the blinding virtuosity may turn some folks off (along with the fleeting silly bits), although I can say that they do back off here and there so it is not completely insane.  Highly recommended to prog fans and fans of jazz rock.some shorter moments where things get slightly jazzy and Chick's acoustic piano and Stanleys' acoustic bass work can be heard (The Romantic Warrior).  For the most part though, these moments are far and few between and this is pretty much a rock record.  <br /> <br />This remastered album is OK and features good sound quality and restored album cover art, with some informative liner notes. <br /> <br />As a fan of both prog and jazz rock, this album works for me on a number of levels.  I suppose though, that the blinding virtuosity may turn some folks off (along with the fleeting silly bits), although I can say that they do back off here and there so it is not completely insane.  Highly recommended to prog fans and fans of jazz rock.
0790729393|4.0|The society drama \\"Sleepers\\" from Barry Levinson tells the spectacular story of four boys (Brad Pitt and Jason Patric i.a.), <br />who grow up in a violent neighbourhood, called Hell's Kitchen. After a simple prank, which goes wrong, their lives change completely. They are sentenced to Wilkinson School for Boys where horrible incidents happen. 15 years later in a new life, they decide to take revenge... <br />The story is based on the book with the same title, but it is not settled if it is really autobiographical. Worth mentioning are the well chosen camera techniques, which reflect the people's <br />feelings and the dramatic events. Because of these effects you can identify with the characters. The presentation of several characters is well done by Robert de Niro, who characterizes the priest \\"Father Bobby\\" and also the ward \\"Sean Nokes\\" is very well performed by Kevin Bacon, who conveys the malignance in a special way. The only aspect, which has to be critizised is the difficult story, which is hard to follow at some stages. With this masterpiece Levinson proves his talent by creating a realistic atmosphere and keeping up tension during the whole film.  <br />This film is worth being nominated for an \\"Oscar\\" ! <br /> <br />Written by : Andreas, Simone, Dina from the GBG School in Germany, Remscheid

0790729393|4.0|The movie \\"Sleepers\\" is based on a novel and tells the story of four boys who grow up in Hell's Kitchen, a part of New York, where crime is a normal daily act.  <br />As they commit a prank when they are still young they are sentenced to spend a few months in a detention center. This punishment changes their whole lives because they are sexually abused and later two of them even become murderers. <br />Brad Pitt, who plays one of the four main characters, gives a convincing performance because you can really feel what it must be like for the boys to live a normal life although they have been abused. <br />One actor plays the role of the boy who comments on the whole story. Like Brad Pitt he also gives a detailed inside of the deep feelings of an abused boy who is trying to live a normal life.  <br />Other famous actors in the movie are Dustin Hoffmann, who portrays convincingly the role of a drug addicted and alcoholic lawyer, and Robert DeNiro who gives a strong impression of a Father who seems to be the only person whom the boys can deeply trust.  <br />The feelings are supported by different camera techniques such as many close-ups of the characters' faces and a lot of flashbacks which underline the cruel memories of the boys.  <br />If it has one fail it is that sometimes there are too many cuts which follow each other too fast. <br />The trial at the end of the movie seems to be too long and gives the viewer an impression of boredom. <br />All in all the story conveys a sense of depression. So the movie as a whole may not be for everyone, but you cannot walk away from it without being impressed by the deepness of the story. <br /> <br />Julia B., Alexandra T., Andrea S., Moritz G., Melanie P.

B0009OTGWU|5.0|The watch is big, so be prepared for a big bold thing dangling from your wrist.<br /><br />The functions of the watch are just amazing. Everything works as it should. You cant expect a watch with all these functions to be accurate to the minutest detail.For what you paid for, this is pure technology in your wrist.<br /><br />For those that whine about how it was off or this or that, read the manual, it says that you can recalibrate the watch if it ever gets magnetized by constant exposure to large speakers (like placing the watch on a huge woofer)or other things. The compass will also be off by a marging of 15 degress, if you are standing under huge powerlines. Which is completely understandable. Its a electronic sensor and not a magnetic needle. The manual is pretty thick, read it carefully and then try to understand its functions and how it works and you will not be dissapointed.<br /><br />Make sure to place the watch on constant light whenever you can to get the solar cells running.<br /><br />Other than being  little big on your wrist, i have no complaints.

B000HBK3MM|3.0|This English beauty has an exquisite voice. She brings an aura of innocence and purity that's quite rare in today's artists and in the music industry in general. Her music takes you places, and that's what makes this album just a wonderful treat. However, I agree with some people who think that she's overly compared to other artists, such as Billie Holiday, Eryka Badu, Norah Jones, and Jill Scott. That's a problem. It makes it hard to listen to her voice without thinking about those artists. In some ways it makes her just another pretty girl who has a voice of gold that could be heard in every blues, slow jazz, and R&B station in the country. I think that's the downfall about artists such as Corrinne and Norah Jones--their music is admired, but they're overly compared to blues artists from long ago, so much to the point that they're underlooked and tend to fade, leaving people to barely know these artists for who they are.<br /><br />Personally, I found this album to be pretty consistent. A few pretty songs, but no track stood out, except the obvious hit single, \\"Put Your Records On.\\" I found the more upbeat songs to lack something. I guess not much rhythm or excitement, kind of dull and boring. With a voice so soft and delicate, an R&B flair kind of makes it sound out of character and pretty dry. And I found many of the tracks to be a bit too repetitive. No surprises, no different sound, just kind of the same soft and pretty vibe.<br /><br />But this girl has something. Maybe not something special or different, but it's nice to hear a new artist who isn't about rebelling against the world and trying to showoff her sex appeal like most artists. It's just pure innocence, nice, simple, subtle music, nothing more or less.
0061015725|5.0|Just finished reading this book. Compared with the last fiction novel I read - Baldacci's The Winner - this is a far, far better written and researched book. \\"Prey\\" holds your interest, has a good plot, and the pace is well maintained. The details at times may bore those uninterested in the minutaue, but the technical gore is kept to a minimum. The pace at which the bio-engineered nanoparticles evolve is a bit too fast to be entirely plausible, or the level of sophistication that they become capable of within a few weeks, but is well presented to make it at least a little bit plausible. Also, the stay-at-home father routine of Jack Forman is presented in excruciating detail, especially in the first few pages of the book, but this also is a minor quibble with the book. All in all, a full five stars.

Sadly, their music has taken second place in the eyes of many.  <br /> <br />I enjoy \\"American Idiot,\\" I have listened to it-hell, I even own it-and I have to credit it as one of the albums that introduced me to rock n' roll in general. B000FA57RQ|5.0|Madonna's come a long way since 1991 \\"Truth or Dare\\", and this film is evident of that.  Although I am a Madonna fan, I'm a pretty objective one and don't enjoy everything she's done (especially when it comes to film).  \\"I'm Going To Tell You A Secret\\", though, is a very enjoyable film...and a much more insightful and introspective film then I had expected.  It's worth viewing. <br /> <br />While 1991's documentary of her \\"Blond Ambition\\" tour found Madonna being scandalous, brat-like, and at the complete and total peak of her, then, uber-popularity...\\"I'm Going To Tell You A Secret\\" finds her in a very different place (which documents 2004's phenomenally successful \\"Re-Invention Tour\\").  Here we find Madonna 20 + years into her career, and in a much different place.  She's a mother now, she's far more approachable, and she's on a journey (which she has made very public) to find \\"the truth\\" so to speak via her newfound spirituality (via the Kabbalah). <br /> <br />Is this documentary as fun, exciting, and controversial as her 1991 documentary?  Absolutely not.  BUT, it's just as interesting in another sense: Madonna now sees that she has a responsibility as a public figure, but more importantly, she has a responsibility to herself and her family.  Her responsibility lies in many areas, but with this film, she focuses mainly on exuding positive energy to the world, being devoted to her family, and being devoted to her spirituality. <br /> <br />The film is inter-cut with beautiful color concert footage (the remainder of the documentary is mainly black and white).  This film is worth watching...for fans, but especially for people who aren't fans because it makes you *think* about what you would like to do with your own life, what you're doing with it, and who and how you're sharing it with those around you. <br /> <br />Madonna may no longer be wearing cones on stage, but it doesn't make her any less interesting.  This film proves that. <br /> <br />It's too bad thisfilm didn't get a theatre release.  The DVD also comes with a live soundtrack of some songs from the concert (the tracks on the CD are of full-length, while the DVD has slightly edited live performances). <br />

I disagree with the reviewers who found it to be a \\"McBook.\\"  It is true that, like most authors, Grisham doesn't always deliver -- but he certainly does in this one!  I couldn't put this book down once I had started.  It is the story of two boys, who see something terrible -- a suicide.  But before that, one of the boys is told something dreadful by the man -- a secret that the mob wants, the police want, the FBI wants.  How the eleven-year old boy deals with that, and the folks who help him, is what this book is about.  It would make a great movie (if iut hasn't already been made into one!).  I enjoyed every word of it.

0141301066|3.0|Matilda Wormwood is one of the youngest protagonists in YA literature, but don't be fooled by her small stature; she is a genius when it comes to reading and performing mathematical processes in her head.  Her clueless and callous parents ignore her prodigy--leaving her alone all afternoon. Encouraged by a kind librarian and later by a sweet teacher, Miss Honey, little Matilda at 5 sets herself to reading British and American adult Classics.   <br /> <br /> Her father is a dishonest used car salesman who prizes their son, but his unreasonable punishment of Matilda merely serves to inspire her ingenuity for private revenge.   Naturally modest and well-behaved the little girl is pushed to domestic extremes.  All of which proves a prelude to her greatest challenge--the horrendously malicious Headmistress, Miss Trunchbull.  Can a tiny tyke, even with her super brain, outwit and banish the school's entrenched bully? <br /> <br />     This is a delightful read for kids of all ages, as Matilda matches wits with dishonesty on several levels.  There is hope for two lonely females who need and deeply appreciate each other.  This charming book is funny yet thoughtful, as the author takes literary potshots at his own sadistic teachers.  With Dahl one can be sure that social and personal justice will eventually triumph! <br /> <br />  <br /> <br />

The hooks will get in your head and you'll be singing them in no time. Great solo there.  <br /> <br />We're Going Wrong is excellent. The atmosphere is set up by Ginger's drums, and then Eric joins in with a soft guitar and then some nice licks. I like Jack's vocals on this. And while the Holocaust is an issue that needs to be handled with delicacy and reverence, the film seems to treat it with none of the severity or candor it deserves.  The entire point of the TITLE is how the past becomes illuminated and thereby illuminates the present, so that EVERYTHING IS ILLUMINATED.  Yer the past in this movie is given barely a nod, and the character of Jonathan learns virtually nothing about his grandfather, and so has changed almost not at all except in some cryptic way Wood seems to imply with an unmotivated smile.  I'm all for letting the visuals do the work instead of the dialogue, but you need to establish a connection to your characters first.  I finished thebook feeling like I'd had the wind knocked out of me.  I finished the film going \\"Well what was the point?\\"  Why was this made if Schreiber didn't appreciate any of the reasons it needed to be made?   <br />Waste of time. <br />Read the book. <br />Really.
B0006J28KU|5.0|When it comes to reviewing a film that's been reviewed so many times as Michael Mann's Heat, original comments are difficult to make. Instead it seems more appropriate to use this review space to urge fans of crime dramas/action movies to check out Heat! Chances are you'll end up buying it.<br /><br />One of the greatest things about the movie is the cast - stellar performances by Al Pacino, Val Kilmer, John Vought, and Robert de Nero make this film an excellent drama and compelling on an emotion level. Coupled with an excellent script, amazing cinematography, a fast pace, non-stop action and engaging storyline, Heat stands apart from other police crime dramas as something rather exquisite.<br /><br />The fast paced story might remind the viewer of Tarantino's \\"Pulp Fiction,\\" and yet isn't as disjointed as that film in execution (something which Tarantino is famous for). The dramatic elements might remind the audience of Mike Newell's \\"Donnie Brasco.\\" But whatever link this film has to either of the two, that's just where the connection ends. Heat is truly a masterpiece of its own kind onto itself.<br /><br />As for this version of Heat, surprisingly although I like the commentaries and extras found within the twin DVD pack, I think they could have done more with the DVDs. For instance, unless it's a problem with the 4 DVD players I tested the movie on, the audio is somehow rather poor. Beside from that I'm pretty neutral as to which version of the movie should best be purchased.<br /><br />If crime dramas interest you, then check out Heat today. If you're a Michael Mann fan, this is probably one of his greatest works since Miami Vice the television show so you should either see it or buy it today.

B000HBK3MM|4.0|Corinne Bailey Rae made a good debut performance on the UK's most respected late-night music programme before Christmas last year, and drew ringing praise out of none other than Burt Bacharach. That, coupled with the record company's insistance that she has the voice to put her up there with Billie Holiday, means that she has an awful lot to live up to. It's impossible, as Como once said. <br /> <br />My initial reaction to this CD upon trying to listen to it was to go in the complete opposite direction. For a start it took five attempts to listen all the way through without nodding off to sleep, because it's so easy, one-paced, and over-produced to within an inch of its life. So the temptation was to dismiss it to the cure-for-insomnia or after-dinner-party categories; however, something has made me persevere with it and has convinced me that it's more than just that. <br /> <br />I can't really see the likeness to Holiday myself, I think it's insulting to both ladies. If it's true that you're influenced by what you hear growing up at home, then I suspect the family record collection boasts some Sade, Sly Stone, Curtis Mayfield, and, from the \\"mockney\\" intro to \\"Put Your Records On\\", some All Saints. Corinne's voices sounds very pure and natural, and it's very English (no trace of Leeds (Yorkshire) though). I'm not sure how strong it is - the nature of the songs is such that she's closely-miked and intimate, and they certainly don't warrant or get any vocal gymnastics - but you can hear every word quite clearly, which is fairly remarkable. <br /> <br />The songs themselves are all self-penned, with help in the music department from various members of her backing band. The lyrics are simple and beautiful - some may say too much so - of her experiences in love and, in the second half of the album, of growing up at home. The music is that easy, soul-lite pop, with the flavour here and there of gospel, jazz, dub and R&B. Apart from the lead single / airplay track \\"PutYour Records On\\" none of them sound instantly commercial, but they do grow on you, particularly the first six. Track seven, \\"Choux Pastry Heart\\" is a great title, but a sad song with a dreary, jazz-pretentious melody and things never recover from that, despite some bassy dub grooves in \\"I'd Like To\\". <br /> <br />Corinne plays guitar and percussion on most of the songs, so she's not just a pretty face. It's all very well produced - reading the credits they threw everything at it except the proverbial kitchen sink - but, apart from some overheated bass guitar on some tracks, it doesn't sound too artificial, just warm and comfortable. Yes, this will inevitably join the easy-listening pile along with many other similar young hopefuls these days, but Corinne's voice and songs are sufficiently different, in a pure and innocent way, to deserve listening to more closely.

B0009I7NNA|2.0|This band is one of those bands that is really, really, really fun to watch and listen to... provided nobody takes them seriously.  Unfortunately... we've crossed that threshold long ago.  So now we're left with this interesting, but hardly qualitative, band in our midst.<br /><br />The thing is, they really do try to do things with their music, and in most of their songs I've heard it seems they switch to about five or six different genres of music.  The problem is that they do none of them well.  It works for a local band trying to build themselves together and discover their own tune, something that a small dedicated fanbase can show pamphlets to their shows in dusty bars over college campuses and large high-schools, but it doesn't work for actually devoting airtime and fan-clubs over.  They needed a few more years of obscurity, some time to clean up their sound and figure out what they really wanted to do (I'm not talking genre, I'm talking cohesiveness), before being released in the broader spectrum of marketability.<br /><br />But oh, silly me, forgetting that stuff like \\"quality\\" and \\"dependability\\" has any place in the current consumerist marketplace.  There goes me proselytizing on ideals again.<br /><br />So let's get give them some of the benefit of the doubt: first of all, they could prove to be highly inspiring to someone who wants to take the experimentation further, and who might do it right.  Secondly, they might get enough room in their touring and marketing to hit on something really good, and their sound might develop despite the fact that commonly these situations tend to degrade into blessed obscurity.<br /><br />In the meantime, they sure are cute little fledgling rockers, now aren't they?<br /><br />--PolarisDiB

It is a \\"non-fictional memoir,\\" as referred to by James Frey.  It tells a story about addiction, alcoholism, about recovery, family, friends, faith, love and hope.  Not until recently, does James admit that \\"...I embellished many details about my past experiences, and altered others in order to serve what I felt was the greater purpose of the book.  I sincerely apologize...\\"  He claims the book was altered by the mind of a recovering drug addict and alcoholic. <br /> <br />The publishers for Doubleday and Anchor Books have \\"...sadly come to the realization that a number of facts have been altered and incidents embellished.\\"  As a result of James Frey's lies and misconceptions, all books that will now be printed will contain a note to the reader from the author himself stating that the book is a memoir, based on facts about his life and certain embellishments.   <br /> <br />The world renowned Oprah Winfrey described James Frey's book as a \\"radical departure\\" and the man that kept her awake at night. A Million Little Pieces was selected for her book club, perhaps the world's most powerful book club.  Due to the publicity, the \\"memoir\\" sold 3.5 million copies and stayed at the top of New York Times nonfiction paperback for fifteen weeks.  James lied and cheated his readers and those who publicized his story and made a fortune doing it. <br />

The most haunting being Sidney's visit to the movie set and seeing the exact replica of her and Stu's home from Woodsboro and viewing the scene of Tatum's demise. The opening sequence is also well done, but not as good as the other two. Parker Posey does steal the film as Jennifer Jolie and Neve Campbell is always good as Sidney Prescott.  <br /> <br />An early sequence where a member of a class that Gale Weathers is lecturing asks her if after all the terror that has occured, it was really worth going after the story. That to me would've been a starting point to a similar but different plot.  <br /> <br />My plot would consist of this: There is a third film being done in the Stab series, but they would actually shoot in the town of Woodsboro, which has the community up in arms. The attacks by the killer would be directed at the cast, but instead of just pictures of Maureen Prescott: the killer would leave pictures of all the victims starting with Maureen or maybe Casey Becker(Drew Barrymore). There would be another reporter but their story would cover the human element of the story, interviewing family members of the victims. As the body count mounts, a secret would be revealed about the Prescott family and the real reason for all the trouble would be revealed in the final act that would take place at the house where it all started.  <br /> <br />I think the First two films are fine book ends, but the third one sticks out like a sore thumb.
B00005JNEI|1.0|This film epitomizes what liberals are fanatic about: placing importance on appearance rather than substance. B00004Z4SD|5.0|You're probably wondering how good a movie about an old man's journey from Iowa to Wisconsin on a riding lawn mower could be and the answer would surprise you - it's VERY good.  \\"Straight Story\\" is a quiet, slow-paced movie with sparse dialogue, great cinematography, superb acting, and an interesting character-driven movie that is a profound statement on fighting inner demons and reconciliation.  \\"Straight Story\\" relays the true story of Alvin Straight, a 73 year-old diabetic who can no longer drive.  Hobbled and in failing health Straight would appear broken to the casual observer but his spirit and will remain very alive.  Learning his estranged brother, Lyle, has had a stroke Alvin decides he must go be with his brother.  With single-mindedness Alvin strikes upon riding his lawn mower from Western Iowa to his brother's home in Wisconsin.  The vehicle is perfect for Alvin's limited faculties and he refuses to consider someone else driving him or his taking the bus.  His is a solitary quest and after a false start Alvin sets off on his journey.  After a false start Alvin sets off on his journey.<br /><br />Straight's journey involves challenges great and small which he meets with a quiet stoic dignity.  The scenes of his journey are loaded with symbolism and imagery rarely seen in contemporary film.  Richard Farnsworth's expressive face and eyes say more than any dialogue ever could and he truly deserved the Oscar for this performance (he was nominated, but lost).  Along the way Alvin encounters a number of people and these moving vignettes serve as confessions for his past misdeeds.  The closer Alvin comes to his goal the greater the challenges.  The ending is almost anti-climactic and leaves the viewer to create their own ending as the film ends against a starry backdrop.<br /><br />\\"Straight Story\\" is at once recognizably Lynchian in its odd flawed characters, use of super-saturated colors, and dynamic tension.  Unlike other Lynch movies there are moments of hilarity and quiet solitude.  \\"Straight Story\\" focuses on the turmoil within, not the surface terrors as in other Lynch films such as \\"Blue Velvet.\\"  A movie of quiet dignity, perseverance, and reconciliation it is profoundly moving and memorable.hilarity and quiet solitude.  \\"Straight Story\\" focuses on the turmoil within, not the surface terrors as in other Lynch films such as \\"Blue Velvet.\\"  A movie of quiet dignity, perseverance, and reconciliation it is profoundly moving and memorable.

B0009R1T7M|5.0|After forcing Sufjan Stevens's \\"John Wayne Gacy, Jr.\\" on a friend, I received something like the following response: \\"It's just not right that someone should write a song like that about a serial killer.\\"  I think my friend was, begrudgingly, admitting the surprising power the song has.  It's not often one is asked to be moved to pity a serial killer, and it can't help but be a disturbing experience.<br /><br />What makes the song so very powerful?  It's certainly not in the words alone, but in Sufjan's really amazing ability to use music simultaneously to capture the general essence and to highlight the specifics of his poem.<br /><br />Take the piano part: it absolutely, categorically refuses to adhere to the beat, which is followed in a very straightforward manner in both the guitar and vocals.  The guitar and vocals are OUR minds--the narrator's, the observer's--watching Gacy from afar.  The piano, on the other hand, is Gacy's mind, the mind of the madman out of sync with the rest of the world.<br /><br />Significantly, though, both narrator and madman reach their musical climax at exactly the same point--roughly two-thirds through the composition (and here we have the golden mean)--during the line \\"He put a cloth. . .\\"  This is the moment of death for Gacy's faceless victim.  The piano reaches its highest note (tonic, if music analysis does anything for you), and the rest of the ensemble their loudest dynamic.  After the death, the volume and the piano line both fall; they are exhausted by the experience, spent.<br /><br />Sufjan can only take the briefest moment of denouement to consider what has happened: \\"I am really just like him.\\"  He has already shown us this musically by matching the madman and narrator's climax.  The almost unfathomable comparison has been made musically tangible, musically true, and the musical possibility of comparison makes the REAL possibility suggested in the poem's somber conclusion all the more frightening.

B000BMSTMS|5.0|if you ever liked Korn, Limp Bizkit, System of a Down, or any of those late-90s nu metal/metal bands... buy this album. go now. stop reading. shoo!<br /><br />okay, now that you HAVE the album, let me explain why you just bought it. \\"See You on the Other Side\\" is Korn returned to their most profitable roots. not all the way back to the days when their albums were more rage than music, but to roughly the sound you knew from \\"Follow the Leader;\\" the sound that catapulted their breakout onto the world stage. take \\"Twisted Transistor,\\" for example, here you have a rollicking good time of a song with Korn's original trademark make-you-jump-up-and-down-and-onto-your-friends crunchy guitar riffs. lots of foot-stomping good times to be found in this song and on this album. the wailing melodies of jon davis' pointed and often abrasive lyrics play off his stacatto vocal mymics of guitar and bass as beautifully as they did on \\"Freak on a Leash.\\" and the heavy thud of drums and bass add the kick to the gritty scratch of so many catchy riffs that you'll be tapping your feet and jamming on air guitar all day long. needless to say, if by the end of this new cd you haven't taken at least one turn of your living room stomping your feet, nodding your head, flailing your arms, and wishing you had something to break that you wouldn't have to pay for, you clearly weren't listening.<br /><br />still, \\"See You on the Other Side\\" isn't precisely a return to the once-ways of Korn. gone are the lyrics so filthy they'd make the boys from Slipknot or Bloodhound Gang sick to their stomachs. and gone are the collaborations with such notables as Snoop Dogg and Fred Durst; though you can see Snoop and some other high profile rappers of yester-year on the recently released video for \\"Twisted Transistor\\" (a must-watch on MTV, btw). i for one am thrilled at the demise of these two ubiquitous elements of previous Korn albums. i never really liked what Jon and the guys cut at their most filthy, or with their friends from other groups. Korn to me is about balling your angst up and tossing it out of your body like a shot-putter as you careen into other black-clad, pasty, thin, white boys packed like sardines in a huge concert hall. and that comes from the riffs, the drums, and - occassionally - jon's bagpipes. i was always disappointed when the songs turned appallingly dirty or included vocals by someone who just laid down a carpet of obscenity over which jon's lyrics could sometimes be discerned.<br /><br />so you can imagine my delight when the b-side of this album wasn't a hodge-podge of duets about homosexual band rivalries or hurting little boys. rather, it is a new forray for Korn into more heavily program-dependant music. now don't think i'm talking about a Static-X b-side here. This isn't \\"Wisconsin Death Trip\\" for all you closet techno lovers who feel entirely too white to learn how to rave. oh no, this is just Korn with a little electronic garnish. but trust me, you'll dig it.<br /><br />so there you have it. if you haven't added this item to your cart yet, i have but one question to ask: what are you waiting for?with their friends from other groups. 6304806426|5.0|Ralph Fiennes plays the handsome Hungarian Count Laszlo Almassy who is a quiet, intense, sensitive educated man. His complicated life is unraveled thread by thread in this deeply inspiring, adventurous and biographical film about love and survival. He awakens in a British hospital without identification and is simply called \\"the English patient\\". His face is scarred beyond recognition, his hands are contracted from scar tissue ... The haunting exotic lyrics to the song \\"Szerelem Szerlem\\" (Love Love) as sung by Marta Sebestyen is heard occasionally throughout the film. It very appropriately symbolizes the basis of his actions and life story. Count Almassy demonstrates courage, resourcefulness, and integrity when he does everything in his power to keep is word and rescue the life of the woman he loves, Katherine Clifton played by Juliette Binochet. In the end, whatever he did was just not enough ... yet he survived.<br /><br />The film begins in Indiana Jones fashion, the cinematography is outstanding as two biplanes fly over mountains and sand dunes ... visible as far as the eye can see. The views are stupendous! Count Almassy is a pilot who leads a British group to some mountains which were described by a Bedouin. They discover a cave which has magnificent archeological value: simple drawings on the walls of ancient man's activities ... Katherine Clifton, the wife of a British mapmaker, is captivated and makes drawings which she offers to Laszlo Almassy. There is an interesting tension between them which later in the film develops into intense feelings of love upon which most of the story is based. Other memories surface of the sand dunes, Count Almassy is rescued by Bedouins who cover his burned face with a wet cloth, wrap his body in a blanket, place him on an immmobilizer and transport him to their camp where they treat his wound with unguent and herbal remedies, essentially saving his life ...<br /><br />The story line unfolds in different time segments, as the memories of the English patient awaken ... this makes the film especially interesting and provides unique perspectives and reveals his life story in a more suspense-filled and intriguing manner. After World War II is declared over, he is transported in Italy by the Allies ... prior to crossing bridges and along the roads, several soldiers check for buried unexploded land-mines left by the enemy. Hanna who is the nurse caring for the English patient lends money to a girlfriend who happily joins a group that will celebrate in town. Within minutes, her jeep explodes from a bomb which kills all the passengers. Hannah is so overcome by her friend's death she runs to the site and starts walking to the wreck ... the mine sweepers stop her so she is not injured right after she retrieves her friend's gold bracelet.<br /><br />After the explosion, Hanna (Kristin Scott Thomas) wants to settle in a monastery she spied on a hillside to care for the English patient until help arrives to rescue them. She talks the mobile hospital unit into moving him into one of the empty rooms of the bombed out building. They leave her to her ministrations. The English patient has a book which he cherishes. It is filled with a few items and momentoes of his past life. He opens up and talks about his life to Hannah as she asks him about the significance of his souvenirs. He reveals his deep relationship with Catherine and how it developed ... They acquire another guest Carravegio, a self-described thief who knew one of Hanna's nurse friends and who comes to learn the identity of the English patient. His original plans were to strangle the English patient, whom he suspected was a German spy but after he learned the circumstances of why he had given maps to the Germans his feelings for revenge evaporated. The thief described his experiences during the war which included some graphic torture scenes (I had to close my eyes, I just could not watch it) ...<br /><br />Hanna is shown to be a vulnerable sensitive nurse who needs to feel love and companionship. She develops a relationship with one of the Sikh soldiers named Kip who was a minesweeper. One of the most beautiful scenes in the films is when Kip rigs a pulley system with a seat to show her the artistic murals on the walls of a local church ... However, after Kip's coworker and minesweeper friend dies in an explosion, he withdraws into himself and the relationship with Hanna dissolves. Hanna begins to accept that at times she needs to just let go of people about whom she cares and loves. She learns to accept it is not within her power to correct and solve every problem. This is a very powerful film that touches many emotions within the viewer. It shows how the human spirit can overcome many adversities when the power of love is unleashed. It is no surprise the film won nine Academy Awards, including Best Picture of the Year ... word descriptions are not nearly adequate to describe the true impact of viewing it. B0002Z0EYK|3.0|This movie is quite spectacular and has many things to recommend it. Unfortunately, it has many flaws as well. The great Homer epic still waits for a filmmaker who can do it justice. On balance, though, Wolfgang Petersen's version is worth seeing. I liked the sword fights, particularly the one between Achilles and Hector. I've practiced a form of fencing myself, and I must say that Brad Pitt and Eric Bana did bring the legendary heroes to life! This is exactly how two strong, skillful, reckless young man would fight it out. It was 100% believable, which is very rare in movies.  As an extra bonus, the armor was believable too -- modeled after Greek pottery art.  Achilles shield, however, was very disappointing. According to legend, it was made by Hephaestus, the god of blacksmiths, and the Iliad devotes pages to its description. One would expect a glorious recreation on the screen, but alas. Hollywood's main goal was to keep production costs low and make a crowd pleaser for profit. The effort to please the female audience is especially transparent. So, Brad Pitt strips on several occasions and almost lets a slave girl cut his throat to prove a philosophical point. The hero of heroes, craving for glory on the battlefield, doesn't mind to be slain in bed by a woman... Ha!!  This made me think how each culture reinterprets the stories of the past through the beliefs of the present. The Iliad glorifies the ideals of bronze-age Greece, where a hero's worth was measured by how many men he slew and how many women he raped. There are perhaps a hundred battles in the Iliad and only one family scene. In the movie we have three battles and three love stories, one of which (Achilles and Briseis) is totally made up. At the same time, the moving parting scene of Hector and Andromache gets perhaps 30 seconds on screen. Peter O'Toole delivers an outstanding performance as the old King Priam, whose submission to the will of the gods comes straight from the Iliad. In Homer's tale, theoutcome of the war ultimately depended on which Olympian god was allowed by Zeus to interfere the most. In the movie, the gods exist only in the human mind, and rather mockingly at that.  Nietzsche said gods die when people stop believing in them. This movie demonstrates that the Olympians are dead today. I wonder, will the jealous god of Abraham suffer a similar fate in some future age?

B00006SFLV|2.0|Contrary to what a recent reviewer (from the UK) said, cheap DVD sets from the UK are bootleg, not original, and their video quality is terrible. Still, they gave me an opportunity to watch this series, which I'd only recently become interested in. The series itself is curiously disappointing, as some other reviewers have said.    I grew up long before the 90s, and I see little if anything of myself in it. I can't speak for the millions who do, but they've already spoken for themselves. For me it's just entertainment, and one way I evaluate entertainment is by how much I care about what happens.    On the surface, My So-Called Life seems to be full of honesty and intelligence. Production values are impressive. I was enchanted after watching the pilot. But after several more episodes I discovered that I'd stopped caring what happened to any of the characters. I was actually bored with and tired of them all.    The only thing left that was mildly interesting was the erotic charge between Angela and Jordan, the Claire Danes and Jared Leto characters. But even that felt more like something between vampires than living people. It's not love. It has no potential. Nothing could grow out of it. They're more like Louis and Lestat than Juliet and Romeo.    The fact that I'm judging this as if it were a movie instead of a broadcast network TV series says a lot for it. As a TV series it is indeed remarkable and would be even more so today. It's just kind of hollow. It's polished and often clever, but there's very little substance.

B000066C4V|5.0|The upperclass friends and relations of Sir William McCordle (Michael Gambon) arrive at his country house for a weekend of shooting, accompanied by maids, footmen, and valets, all of whom will be staying under one roof. Sir William is a mean-spirited and self-centered old man, married to a much younger, emotionally distant wife (Kristin Scott Thomas), with many family members dependent upon his continuing largesse. The hilariously waspish Countess of Trentham (Maggie Smith), who believes she has a lifetime stipend, arrives with young Mary Maceachran (Kelly MacDonald), who is trying valiantly to become a good lady's maid. Ivor Novello (Jeremy Northam), a Hollywood star, and Morris Weissman (Bob Balaban), a producer of Charlie Chan movies, are the only guests without aristocratic backgrounds and inherited privilege. The atmosphere of the house, filled with venomous \\"friends\\" and relations, soon becomes even more poisonous.<br /><br />The \\"below stairs\\" lives of the servants are also fully revealed, as they share living quarters, eat meals together, tend to the laundry and cooking, and gossip about their employers. The butler Jennings (Alan Bates) and the head housekeeper (Helen Mirren) run the household and try to guarantee that no real-world cares will intrude upon the lives of their employers. Since \\"upstairs\\" and \\"downstairs\\" occasionally meet very privately at night, secrets abound, many of them secrets of long standing. When Sir William is poisoned and stabbed (\\"Trust Sir William to be murdered twice\\"), nearly everyone has a motive for wanting him dead.<br /><br />For director Robert Altman, the primary focus of the film is on the characters, their way of life, and their values, with the murder mystery secondary. Set in late November, the end of the year 1932, the action takes place when this secure aristocratic lifestyle is also nearing its end, something that the arrival of the newly rich Hollywood characters, Novello and Weissman, illustrates. Dramatic cinematography (by Andrew Dunn) emphasizes the cold and rainy dreariness of the weekend, and suggests parallels with the coldness of the dying aristocracy.<br /><br />Interior shots reveal the contrasts between the elegant and mannered lives of the \\"upstairs\\" characters and the hardworking daily lives of the \\"downstairs\\" characters, who adhere to their own rigid social codes. Every detail rings true, and as the characters' lives and interrelationships are revealed obliquely in brief snippets of seemingly unrelated conversations, a broad picture of the upstairs and downstairs lifestyles gradually emerges. Fully developed, many-leveled, wonderfully acted, often funny, and impeccably directed and filmed, this is a film one can watch again and again with delight. Mary Whippledrew Dunn) emphasizes the cold and rainy dreariness of the weekend, and suggests parallels with the coldness of the dying aristocracy. Every detail rings true, and as the characters' lives and interrelationships are revealed obliquely in brief snippets of seemingly unrelated conversations, a broad picture of the upstairs and downstairs lifestyles gradually emerges. I read this book about three years ago, and enjoyed it so much that I still call it one of my favourites.  <br /> <br />The book is about a boy named Michael, who has booked into a house with a run-down garage. He's not allowed to go in there, but boys being boys, he does, and in there he finds a man named Skellig, who requests (correct me if I'm wrong -- three years is a long time) 27 and 53. Michael, being the clever boy that he is, figures it out, and the relationship grows from there. <br /> <br />Michael's next door neighbour is Mina, who is home-schooled, and spends her days learning about William Blake's poetry, making birds out of clay, and drawing. She is the one who teaches Michael (and us) to appreciate all the wonderful little things in life. <br /> <br />This book, although aimed for children, or early teens, is suitable for older readers, too. In my humble opinion, it is never too late to start looking for the miracles that -- you never know! -- might actually exist. <br /> <br />The book is beautifully written. Its characters are tender and lovable, the story heart-wrenching and heart-warming at the same time, and the style of the book is easy and poetic, very moving and imaginative.  <br /> <br />I will definitely read this book again and again, and it will always be one of my all-time favourites.
B000002LND|4.0|I have a theory on \\"greatest hits\\" albums that goes something like this: the more substantial an artist is, and the greater their albums are, the more pointless their greatest hits compilations are likely to be (Just check out the essentially inane greatest hits albums by Stevie Wonder or The Beatles to see what I'm talking about).  And, the inverse is also true, the less substantial the artist, the more important their greatest hits compilations are.  \\"Greatest Hits\\" compilations can be great for introducing someone to artists that they are not familiar with, but with whole albums you get to see the artists' original vision, and I've found that they are usually more rewarding for the listener in the long run (the good ones anyway).  But for some artists, the \\"greatest hits\\" compilation may be the only thing in their catalog worth buying (there are quite a few artists out there that have a few great songs on really crappy albums).  Now that I'm done pontificating, I must say that that is not exactly the case with Madonna because she does have more in her catalog that could be worth discovering, and as an artist she is often more genuine than she normally gets credit for. Yet still, this collection is likely the best buy in her catalog.  This compilation pretty much plays like a good album (helped greatly by both the fact that the songs are sequenced in chronological order, and the fact that the production qualities are so similar throughout).  Few would argue against Madonna's cultural significance (she is likely the biggest pop star of the 80's, challenged only by Michael Jackson), and despite her tendency to use controversy to get attention, she is actually a decent songwriter (I don't care what anyone says :-).  But, unless you are a diehard album completist (with a strong interest in Madonna's work) or you're really into her work from the 90's and beyond (which I think, with just a few exceptions, has actually grown more and more insubstantial, despite the factthat it supposes to have more would-be \\"artistic cred\\" on the surface) you will likely be content with having this as the only selection from her catalog. As I said earlier, I actually think that some of her material is more substantial than she normally gets credit for (unlike the complete drivel being made by the bubblegum pop starlets who have followed and tried to emulate her), but no serious musician or music fan would ever mistake her for a monumental artist.  But, every artist doesn't have to be, and her contemplative songs can still be quite touching (Live to Tell) and her up-tempo stuff can be a whole lot of fun (Holiday!)or even a cross between the two (\\"Borderline\\" would be a perfect example of this).  I've heard many of her 80's albums and they're all at least solid efforts.  This album takes the best from each of them (save for maybe just a few omissions) and puts them on a single CD  It's a plus that this compilation includes the slightly remixed version of \\"Express Yourself\\" which is actually superior to the album version as far as I'm concerned, but the same can't be said for \\"Like a Prayer\\"-the album version of this track is much better.  And, the fact that her funkiest dance song ever, \\"Into the Groove\\" from the soundtrack for \\"Desperately Seeking Susan\\", is included sure doesn't hurt this album's purchase worthiness (I do however agree with the reviewer who said that \\"True Blue\\" and \\"Who's that Girl\\" should have been included here in place of \\"Justify My Love\\" and \\"Rescue Me\\", which should have been placed on her next album instead).  If you have a passing interest in Madonna's work, or in 80's pop culture in general, then you should definitely give this collection a listen.

Nelson is having a difficult time accepting his current situation.  <br /> <br />Sara pries into Nelson's life. Sara has a special gift, helping men with problems. She brings Nelson into her home and into her life for the month of November. For one month, she will dedicate herself to Nelson so he could learn to live a more meaningful life. Why a month? It's long enough to make an impact without having to become too emotionally attached. Sara's life circumstances prevent her from making a lifetime commitment to anyone. Considering Sara's secret illness, she prevents herself from a lifelong commitment to anyone. <br /> <br />Sweet November helps us see what life is meant to be about, to cherish our time with each other. 0743424425|4.0|When I first picked up this book I was extremely dissapointed by it. King's wordy and extremely descriptive writing style were a slight turn off for me...in the beginning. However, the second time I tried reading it I actually stuck with the story and I realized that King's descriptions are actually his literary brilliance. He describes the characters in great detail, and as the plot goes on, you are able to see how the Overlook changes them and the way they think. This is the really chilling part of the story- how easily the characters are rattled. You see the gradual demise of Jack Torrance, and how the Hotel gradually, subtley, eats away at his sanity. In the end, Jack, not the ghosts, is what is truly terrifying. His demise is actually relative to a lot of people as well. Although maybe not attacked by an evil hotel, people everyday are being pressured into doing things they don't want to do, by an \\"outside evil\\".  <br />   However, I was slightly dissapointed. I was expecting more ghosts and scary scenes leading up to the climax. I was expecting to see more of Grady and his family as well. In the end, however, the book is a masterpiece, and its easy to see that King has amazing talent.

B00005JNRY|5.0|I took my kid (age 6) to see \\"Cars\\" last week, not really knowing what to expect.  I've never been into racing, but was attracted by the concept (anyone else remember the shortlived cartoon \\"Wheelie\\"?).  Both of us were able to connect with the humor right away, which like the diverse characters in this film spans several generations.  The concept of a world populated entirely by inanimate vehicles (mostly cars, but a tractor or train here and there) is a relatively original one on the big screen, and the studio must have had a lot of fun with this one.      Character development was terrific--just as each make and model of vehicle has its own technical characteristics in real life, each personality in \\"Cars\\" has its own talents and quirks.  The plot revolves around rookie racer Lightning McQueen, who is part of a 3-way tie for the Piston Cup, and must cross the country to Los Angeles where there will be a tie-breaker between himself, dependable veteran The King, and perpetual second-placer Chick Hicks.      Along the road to Los Angeles, Lightning McQueen's selfishness is the cause of an unintended detour to a little town called Radiator Springs.  Radiatior Springs is a nifty village on route 66 complete with chrome and neon styling that the new interstate left off the map years ago.  Characters include the older and wiser Doc Hudson (Hornet), who has a secret past and manages to mentor Lighting McQueen and teach him a thing or two.  Sally is a Porsche who left fast-paced Los Angeles to settle down in Radiator Springs and open a Motel. 'Mater is the town's friendly (if rusty) towtruck with a true sense of country humor.  Flo runs the service station, Ramon the Paint and Detail shop (always with a new coat!), Luigi the tire store...There really is something for everyone, including a running humorous dialogue between \\"Sarge\\", an Army-regulation olive drab AMC Jeep who runs the local military surplus shop, and Fillmore, a '60's VW Bus with a psychadelic paint job.I'm not going to give away too much detail, I don't want to spoil the experience for fellow viewers.  My kid loved this film and understood the humor.  There were a lot of laugh out loud moments for the both of us.  As a parent, I liked the lessons \\"Cars\\" taught about ethics, hard work, respect, kindness, keeping your word, and the importance of friendship.  Not to mention appreciating things that aren't necessarily brand new or in the fast lane!  A cute movie, fun for the whole family, a reminder that the best things in life are sometimes hidden off the main thoroughfare.  Oh, and hang around past the credits--you WILL be rewarded with the punch line for an earlier gag!
B000BYA5GO|5.0|I think the title of this review says it all, but this is truly a spectacular movie. In retrospect, it's like a guns version of the Johnny Depp movie \\"Blow.\\" <br />Actually in more ways than one. Both films are about men who begin working in illegal businesses while making vast sums of money and watching their dream come true; And then watch their lives crumble around them with time. Also both films received good reviews and featured Oscar worthy performances and scripts but were ignored by the Academy. Nicolas Cage takes a break from playing his loser character (Matchstick Men, The Weather Man, etc.) and instead plays Yuri Orlov, a Ukrainian man who was raised in Brooklyn. Yuri realizes one day that doing what he's been doing isn't working for him, so with the help of his brother Vitaly (Jared Leto, 'Requiem for a Dream') he becomes a private gunrunner delivering to people in places like Sierra Leone, Russia, and Liberia. Meanwhile, Yuri also marries his dream girl Ava Fontaine (Bridget Moynahan, who looks completely different then she did in the movies 'The Recruit' and 'I, Robot') and has a son. The movie says at the end \\"Based on Real Events,\\" which means nothing...I doubt that a man named Yuri Orlov existed but that doesn't make this film any more or less interesting. Writer/Director Andrew Niccol paints a near perfect portrait of a troubled, yet brilliant man who's trying to support his family and make money no matter who or what he risks. This is one of Nicolas Cage's best performances since \\"Leaving Las Vegas.\\" Both Eathan Hawke (That dude who was married to Uma Thurman) and Ian Holm ('From Hell') deliver good supporting work; Especially Hawke who plays an Interpol agent chasing Yuri for years and never truly getting what he wants. The movie presents a great message, something young viewers won't notice sadly enough. This is not only one of the most morally terrific movies of 2005, but it was also one of the best and most overlooked. If you haven't seen thismovie, then just do it. <br /> <br />GRADE: A <br />

006054094X|5.0|I urge you to read this book, which offers a fascinating detective story -- one man's search for proof  -- that an ambitious emperor sent out an enormous Chinese fleet in 1421, to discover and embrace unknown civilizations in order to expand the empire. The fleet included hundreds of ships, over a hundred of which were huge, nine-masted ships 480 feet long, 180 feet wide and several stories high, which included sixty staterooms.  The captial ships were supported by a host of smaller vessels.   <br /> <br />As a result of superior navigation skills and cartography during the perilous two-year voyage, the Chinese developed accurate maps of the coastlines of North and South America, Africa, Antarctica and Australia, at a time when the Europeans had not yet discovered how to calculate longitude. When European explorers sailed west to the Americas, they had access to charts and maps based on Chinese maps, copied and redrawn decades before Columbus's first voyage. <br /> <br />The story starts when a retired British submarine captain investigates an ancient map in a library, discovers an important detail unnoticed by historians for centuries.  Why did he notice? He had used maps and marine charts to sail to the places shown on the map.  He saw four islands out in the western Atlantic that could not be in that location.  The date jumped out at him. The map was drawn decades before Columbus made his voyage to the Americas.  Impossible. <br /> <br />He realizes it is Puerto Rico shown on a map drawn before 1492.  Its name was not given as Puerto Rico, but its characteristics, landforms and position relative to those of its neighbors were known to him. He was intrigued enough to follow up his discovery elsewhere.  Only a seasoned sea captain who had traveled those waters would have recognized the details that electrified him into a ten-year search for proof. <br /> <br />And proof there was.  Find out why there are palm trees in the Caribbean, why South American chickens differ from their European kin, why some Mexican art reflects Chinese styles, why there are Ming ceramics in South America and incorporated into an ancient mosque in East Africa, and how a Chinese artifact was found on the shores of Rhode Island.   Discover evidence of shipwrecked junks preserved in seas all over the world.  More importantly, discover why the absolute power of Chinese emperors, and the reversal of a dynasty's foreign policy resulted in the suppression of the news of this awesome voyage, including the destruction of documents and more. When the remainder of the fleet limped home from a wildly successful two-year voyage, instead of being hailed as heroes, all news of this unimaginable achievement was supressed, as China turned away from the outer world. <br /> <br />The author took no discoveries on face value, searched for proof by traveling the world to follow leads.  He has woven it all into a fascinating account.  He includes a detailed Appendix which directs doubters to the documents, locations, and details he discovered.  The book includes color plates of Chinese artifacts and ancient maps with impeccable provenance.  I am into my second reading of the book, following a trip to China.  It is even better the second time around.
B00004VWAF|5.0|At the time of its release, On the Corner drew the ire of many reviewers because - it was written - it could not be considered a \\"jazz\\" album. The album is brilliant and the only problem I had with the original release on LP was the length; I wanted more music!<br /><br />The dilemma by placing too much faith in the musings of music critics throughout the electric period of Miles was the seemigly placement of each album in a vaccum, as if the artist wasn't building on a concept. And Miles - as always was the case - was creating a sound for concerts and in the studio.<br /><br />By bringing funk to the forefront of the sound, Miles was essentially placing the final paint strokes on a canvas - merging his studio and live ideas in a tight package - that is still misunderstood in 2006.<br /><br />Miles bolstered the sound with a larger studio group, including such regulars like Chick Corea, Herbie Hancock, John McLaughlin, Jack Dejohnette, Dave Liebman and Michael Henderson.<br /><br />A great live companion piece to On the Corner is Dark Magus, which chronicles one of the last concerts before Miles went into a nearly seven year retirement.

B000CEVUIK|4.0|I started watching Stargate Atlantis when it began its syndicated reruns for Season One.  I am a long time Star Trek fan and can't help but make some comparisons.  Although one of the overall arcs of the series is darker than Star Trek (a pending invasion), the style of writing for each episode is light and seems to be more for a general audience relative to Star Trek.  They seem to place emphasis on entertainment over social commentary; however, you may find a lot of the same story formulas (and titles) used in Star Trek revisited in Stargate Atlantis.  It seems to be a very family-friendly series (few sexually explicit situations, if any, but nothing R-rated).  Be aware that some of the 'vampire' aspects of the show may leave younger viewers with nightmares.  All of the characters have good chemistry together and the dialogue tends to be very witty at times (esp. Dr. McKay and Maj Shepperd.) <br />There are many tongue-in-cheek references to Star Trek (TOS) in this series.  E.g. Major Shepherd compared to Kirk as 'always falling in love with alien women', a Scottish doctor that always seems to end up sounding like Scotty. <br />The Stargate series is known for their longevity through the ability to keep costs down; however, the special effects are not compromised. <br />Like others, I started too late to get into SG-1, but watching Stargate Atlantis does not require too much knowledge of SG-1 to get started.  It's a good fix for those of us who are waiting for Star Trek to come back to TV production.
B000FA57RG|4.0|While it's great to have (some of) the Re-invention Tour on CD, it's a little disappointing that what was selected here are tracks that were lip-synched.  Why not include performances like \\"Deeper and Deeper\\", \\"Nothing Fails\\", \\"Don't Tell Me\\" and \\"Crazy For You\\" which were all performed live, and very well I might add.  Having said that, I love the performances of \\"Lament\\", \\"Into the Groove\\" and \\"Holiday\\". <br /> <br />I do enjoy the CD but I can't help but feel that this live CD is a bit of a missed opportunity.
0385512058|5.0|I greedily swallowed a library's copy in a couple of days and was so excited and impressed that ordered own copy at Amazon. This book should be a table book until you practice the ideas it preaches so deep and often that they become organic part of you.    As you may see from the title the book fights isolation and loneliness during a meal. It's not a metaphor though not the gist either. The essence of the book is \\"your network and connections are the pledge of your success; build your network via becoming useful to people, become a hub of connections, eagerly seek opportunities to help others, and never keep score\\".    It may seem that the ideas are not very innovative and it's true - they're not. But Keith succeeds to deliver such a simple message to readers' brains and hearts. A mix of bright and descriptive problem explanation, concrete and pragmatic advice (the book is organized as a set of such), and real life (actually Keith's life) examples makes reading experience gripping and inspiring.    I was quite sceptic when I took this book in my library. It's definitely a challenge to teach somebody on a very basic topic such a network building and nurturing relationships. Readers may soon find the content boring, repetitive, and obvious to keep reading. The problems are known, there is a variety of networking-101 tips published in magazines and the net, and illustrative examples of how right networking changed so-and-so's life. Still Keith amazingly broke the ice of scepticism with the very first pages turning the 'another-business-book-reading' exercise into very pleasant conversation (yes, while reading the book a strong feeling of a dialog doesn't leave you).    The books makes you look at your life's values again from another point of view. I won't re-tell the book's content and ideas here but strongly encourage you to find the book and read it. I wish I found it 15 or 20 years ago but happy that even today I ran across it. I'm sure I'll meet Keith in person one day and we'll eat together:-)
0385495323|5.0|Simon Singh has done an excellent job of narrating the history of codes and ciphers, covering material in quite a comprehensive manner, yet explaining it in a fashion that even readers who are not particularly gifted in mathematics will understand.  His narration of the (frequently military) history surrounding some important events in the history of cryptography added considerable interest for me; there's just enough of it to add another dimension without there being so much that it detracts from the main story.  His decision to include the decipherment of Egyptian hieroglyphics and Cretan Linear B script was a wise one, as well.  As he notes, neither was an attempt to conceal the meanings, but the methods used are exactly parallel to many used in deciphering codes and ciphers. <br /> <br />Highly recommended.
B0006IIKS0|5.0|This is an interesting psychological portrait of a band with definite interpersonal relationship problems.  Metallica hired a psychologist to spend time with them to help them through their individual differences, and the result is a riviting documentary. <br /> <br />Kirk is the quiet one who submerges his ego for the benefit of the group, James is trying to discover how to get in touch with his feelings after a dysfunctional childhood, and Lars is the negative control freak who is in denial.  Eventually, everything comes together, but the fascination lies in the journey.  Former band member Dave Mustaine makes an appearance as the man who blames the group's success for his inability to pick up his life after his struggle with alcoholism. <br /> <br />Oh, yeah, and they can rock like no one else.  Check this one out.

B0004Z33G4|4.0|The packaging design for this boxed set and its individual cover,showing various Stallone's poses from the three films printed in a grey metallic tone,is pretty attractive.    The four stars given are for the movies:the picture quality in widescreen anamorphic 2.35:1 aspect ratio is virtually speckless and the sound in Dolby Digital 5.1 provides adequate punch to each movie and is dynamically enveloping especially during the action sequences (most evident in RAMBO III).  There are no English subtitles except for certain dialogues in certain scenes involving Soviet soldiers in RAMBO III.    Where this edition falls off considerably is in the special features.The much vaunted Metavision Survival Mode,which is rather hit-or-miss, is far from informative much less interesting.LGF has made a bad choice to include this as the special features replacing the DTS track and other featurettes available in the previous Special Edition boxed set.The only fairly interesting playback upgrade is the Metascope,which enables viewers to know titbits about people,places and events as they occur in each movie.    Even so,the Ultimate Edition is not a bad purchase, bearing in mind that the far superior Special Edition is out of print. This edition is quite a recommended offer ONLY for those who haven't owned the trilogy yet.

0743454529|5.0|I don't agree with some of the other reviewers here. Yes, the story is fascinating and not too unreal to be unbelievable. Yes, you expect the story to progress towards one of two endings. But just at the very end there is a surprise twist that leaves you stunned, baffled, angry, in denial and finally somberly accepting. All of the emotions you would expect to feel if the ending of this book actually happened to you. Is that not that objective of great writing, and a truly great book? To pull you into the story and make you feel all of the emotions as if you were living the story yourself. This book accomplishes that and more.  <br /> <br />I think it is one of the best books I have ever read.
